16 hours ago, calabus2 said:

Larian really did everything right with BG3. They went into EA with a solid foundation and plenty of content. They listened to the community and improved every aspect of the game before release. I truly hope they don't shift into bad guy mode after their success. We've seen it so many times with other studios. 

Fingers crossed, the idea that marketing is dead is pretty spot on though. Kerbal Space Program is perhaps a one of those games that would benefit most from not taking the approach of marketing. Communication (as a two way thing) is mega important for what is a niche game, I know people don't want to accept that, but it is.

 

It's the sorta game that needs to be made for its current fanbase first and foremost, and then with them 'on-board' it can start reaching others. But you absolutely don't accomplish that if you alienate your actual fanbase and try videos, and 'branding' instead. I know (personally) no-one who has ever came to Kerbal Space Program, myself excluded, I don't physically know a other player.

 

Reasons for that can be boiled down to a small statement: "The game is too complicated, it's too hard", that's what every single person I've known who has tried Kerbal Space Program has said, and herein lies the crux of the issue. Gamers, as a whole are getting lazier and lazier, more interested in how fast they can use the triggers than anything else.

 

Kerbal Space Program is a game pretty much made for the confines of this forum, and maybe a small amount of people outside that would come over.

 

So, as sad as it is, Kerbal Space Program dies, unceremoniously with Intercept Games and the Call of Duty, FIFA, Grand Theft Auto machine keeps on ticking over and generating millions and millions of sales, vindicating their approach. In the process we lost a genuine 'diamond' amongst coal.
